verses.text: Flee the evil desires of youth, and pursue righteousness, faith, love and peace, along with those who call on the Lord out of a pure heart.
Don't have anything to do with foolish and stupid arguments, because you know they produce quarrels.
And the Lord's servant must not quarrel; instead, he must be kind to everyone, able to teach, not resentful.

rsbNotes.title: 2 Tim 2:23
rsbNotes.text: 2:23 controversies . . . quarrels. See note 2:14.

verses.text: Those who oppose him he must gently instruct, in the hope that God will grant them repentance leading them to a knowledge of the truth,
and that they will come to their senses and escape from the trap of the devil, who has taken them captive to do his will.

rsbNotes.title: 2 Tim 2:25–26
rsbNotes.text: 2:25, 26 The Christian must never assume that those who are ensnared by the devil’s false teaching are irretrievably lost. The gospel must be proclaimed to all.

verses.text: But mark this: There will be terrible times in the last days.
People will be lovers of themselves, lovers of money, boastful, proud, abusive, disobedient to their parents, ungrateful, unholy,
without love, unforgiving, slanderous, without self-control, brutal, not lovers of the good,
treacherous, rash, conceited, lovers of pleasure rather than lovers of God--

rsbNotes.title: 2 Tim 3:1–9
rsbNotes.text: 3:1–9 Paul continues on the theme of false teaching by turning to an attack on the false teachers themselves, noting their impact upon the church at Ephesus, but concluding with the affirmation that they will not succeed in the end.

rsbNotes.title: 2 Tim 3:1
rsbNotes.text: 3:1 the last days. The era inaugurated by Christ’s First Advent and completed by His second (1 Tim. 4:1 note).

verses.text: having a form of godliness but denying its power. Have nothing to do with them.

rsbNotes.title: 2 Tim 3:5
rsbNotes.text: 3:5 having the appearance of godliness, but denying its power. What makes the false teachers so dangerous is that they appear to be Christians (Matt. 7:15, 21–23).

verses.text: They are the kind who worm their way into homes and gain control over weak-willed women, who are loaded down with sins and are swayed by all kinds of evil desires,
always learning but never able to acknowledge the truth.

rsbNotes.title: 2 Tim 3:6
rsbNotes.text: 3:6 weak women. Paul’s point is not that all women are this way, but that some have been especially vulnerable to deception. The false teachers at Ephesus had been especially successful in deceiving women (1 Tim. 2:14; 5:13–15).

verses.text: Just as Jannes and Jambres opposed Moses, so also these men oppose the truth--men of depraved minds, who, as far as the faith is concerned, are rejected.
But they will not get very far because, as in the case of those men, their folly will be clear to everyone.

rsbNotes.title: 2 Tim 3:8
rsbNotes.text: 3:8 Jannes and Jambres. In Jewish tradition, these names were given to two Egyptian magicians who opposed Moses before Pharaoh (Ex. 7; 8).

verses.text: You, however, know all about my teaching, my way of life, my purpose, faith, patience, love, endurance,

rsbNotes.title: 2 Tim 3:10–17
rsbNotes.text: 3:10–17 With the problem of the false teachers fully in view, Paul once more turns to exhorting Timothy to faithfulness, first in terms of the example which Paul has set, and then as obedience to Scripture.

rsbNotes.title: 2 Tim 3:10–11
rsbNotes.text: 3:10, 11 Once again Paul appeals to his own life as an example for Timothy (1:11–13; 2:8–10).

verses.text: persecutions, sufferings--what kinds of things happened to me in Antioch, Iconium and Lystra, the persecutions I endured. Yet the Lord rescued me from all of them.

rsbNotes.title: 2 Tim 3:11
rsbNotes.text:
3:11 Antioch . . . Iconium . . . Lystra. Three cities in the Roman province of Galatia where Paul preached the gospel on his first missionary journey (Acts 13:14–14:20). Against significant opposition, Paul succeeded in establishing a church in each city (Acts 14:21–23). Paul mentions these cities, including Timothy’s home of Lystra, in order to appeal to the roots of Timothy’s faith (vv. 14, 15; 1:5).

the Lord rescued me. See 4:18 and note.

verses.text: In fact, everyone who wants to live a godly life in Christ Jesus will be persecuted,
while evil men and impostors will go from bad to worse, deceiving and being deceived.

rsbNotes.title: 2 Tim 3:12
rsbNotes.text: 3:12 all who desire to live a godly life . . . will be persecuted. The New Testament teaches that Christians should expect persecution (Matt. 10:17, 18; John 15:20; 1 Pet. 4:12; 5:9).

verses.text: But as for you, continue in what you have learned and have become convinced of, because you know those from whom you learned it,

rsbNotes.title: 2 Tim 3:14
rsbNotes.text: 3:14 from whom you learned it. A reference to Timothy’s mother and grandmother (1:5), as well as to Paul himself.

verses.text: and how from infancy you have known the holy Scriptures, which are able to make you wise for salvation through faith in Christ Jesus.

rsbNotes.title: 2 Tim 3:15
rsbNotes.text:
3:15 from childhood. According to custom, the Jewish parent was to begin instructing a child in the law when the child reached five years of age.

you have been acquainted with the sacred writings. The false teachers have been misinterpreting the Old Testament (1 Tim. 1:7; Titus 3:9). Timothy needs to remember the proper instruction he received at the hands of his mother and grandmother. The “sacred writings” here are the books of the Old Testament. The New Testament did not yet exist as a collection. Indeed, some of the New Testament books had probably not yet been written.

salvation . . . in Christ Jesus. The Old Testament, interpreted properly, leads one to understand the central role of Jesus Christ in God’s overall plan for His Creation.

verses.text: All Scripture is God-breathed and is useful for teaching, rebuking, correcting and training in righteousness,
so that the man of God may be thoroughly equipped for every good work.

rsbNotes.title: 2 Tim 3:16
rsbNotes.text:
3:16 All Scripture. The Old Testament (v. 15 note).

breathed out by God. This is one of the most important expressions in the New Testament of the doctrine of the divine inspiration of Scripture. The Bible has been breathed out by the Spirit of God (2 Pet. 1:21). God is the source and ultimate Author of Scripture. Though written by human authors, Scripture nevertheless has the full weight of His authority. See theological note “The Authority of Scripture.”
